headline: CNN Special Reports
subHeadline: CNN Special Report: Royal Revolution: Harry and Meghan. Aired 11p-12a ET

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: More empathetic and less prejudiced. Yes.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Yes. Right.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: This idea that we out of this marriage we can raise children who see the world differently, who treat people differently. Just the very fact that we are united in this way can teach us so much about what it means to love people who are different.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: One, two, three.

utterances.speaker: ANNOUNCER
utterances.sentences: The following is a CNN Special Report.ALIYN CAMEROTA, CNN HOST (voice-over): He was the party prince.

utterances.speaker: PENNY JUNOR, ROYAL BIOGRAPHER
utterances.sentences: For many years it was a real worry about what would happen to Harry.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: Who rebelled against royalty.ANGELA LEVIN, AUTHOR, "HARRY: CONVERSATIONS WITH THE PRINCE": He decided he might leave the royal family.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: Haunted by his mother's death.

utterances.speaker: ROYA NIKKHAH, ROYAL EDITOR, THE SUNDAY TIMES
utterances.sentences: It destabilized him and caused chaos for years.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: He struggled to find his way.PAUL BURRELL, PRINCESS DIANA'S BUTLER: Being royal for Harry was a burden and a curse.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: She's a former American actress.

utterances.speaker: PRINCE HARRY, DUKE OF SUSSEX
utterances.sentences: I was like, I said why do we have to elope?  (INAUDIBLE).

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: Unlike any royal bride before.

utterances.speaker: KATE COYNE, EXECUTIVE EDITOR, PEOPLE MAGAZINE
utterances.sentences: If you go back a few generations, everything about Meghan Markle disqualifies her for marrying Harry.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: A modern royal couple changing history.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED REPORTER
utterances.sentences: The Duke and Duchess say they will step back as senior members of the royal family.

utterances.speaker: JUNOR
utterances.sentences: Harry decided I'm going to look after my wife in a way that I wasn't able to look after my mother.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: And redefining royalty.(On-camera): What do you think the future looks like for Harry and Meghan. CAROLYN DURAND, CO-AUTHOR, "FINDING FREEDOM": The sky's the limit. They're going to harness the power that they have as public individuals to change the world. CAMEROTA (voice-over): Tonight a CNN Special Report, "ROYAL REVELATION: HARRY AND MEGHAN. September 15th, 1984. Prince Henry Charles Albert David was born.

utterances.speaker: BURRELL
utterances.sentences: Harry came into the world very different to his brother who is heralded as the next in line to the throne of England. That Harry was the spare.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: Paul Burrel was Princess Diana's butler.

utterances.speaker: BURRELL
utterances.sentences: So all through Harry's formative years he always knew that he was second.

utterances.speaker: JUNOR
utterances.sentences: He was always referred to as the spare, just always second best. And I think that had a profound effect on Harry.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: His childhood was also impacted by his parents' marital troubles.

utterances.speaker: JUNOR
utterances.sentences: Harry grew up in a very tricky, very household. The prince and princess were never happy together in a marriage that had failed before it even began.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: When Charles and Diana divorced, it hit Harry hard, then one year later his mother was killed. Harry was just 12 years old.

utterances.speaker: NIKKHAH
utterances.sentences: This incredibly loving figure who had given him so much warmth and comfort in what was a very difficult childhood and extraordinarily upbringing was suddenly gone.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: Harry later admitted to iTV he struggled to process her death.

utterances.speaker: PRINCE HARRY
utterances.sentences: It was a classic case of don't let yourself think about your mom and the grief and the hurt that comes with it because it's never going to bring her back and it's only going to make you more sad. People deal with grief in different ways, and my way of dealing with it was by just basically shutting it out, locking it out.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: Prince Harry arrived at Eaton, a prestigious boys boarding school the year after his mother's death. Even though he moved into the same house as his older brother Willam, Harry reportedly struggled academically and was miserably.

utterances.speaker: BURRELL
utterances.sentences: Diana always said that she never wanted Harry to go to Eaton because he would be compared to his brother's success. And she thought this would be the undoing of Harry's confidence.

utterances.speaker: LEVIN
utterances.sentences: Prince Harry said that he decided that he was going to be a bad boy so that the reason he didn't do well there was partly his fault. It's deliberate.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: In 2002 headlines emerged of Harry's drinking and marijuana use.(On-camera): Did it seem to Brits that it was more than just typical teenage antics?

utterances.speaker: JUNOR
utterances.sentences: It's all part of the growing up process but I personally was worried that there was something deeper. There was a touch of self- medication going on.CAMEROTA (voice-over): After graduating from Eaton, Harry escaped to Africa during his gap year for humanitarian work.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: He spent two months in Lesotho with children in need and others whose parents had died from AIDS.

utterances.speaker: NIKKHAH
utterances.sentences: He could see that there were holes there in their lives, and I think absolutely he saw in them something that he felt was missing in his life -- care, love, and attention, the loss of his mother.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: Harry not only fell in love with the children in the country he began a serious romance with a wealthy girl from Southern Africa, Chelsy Davy.

utterances.speaker: NIKKHAH
utterances.sentences: She's very free spirited, not someone who felt bound by world protocol or tradition, and also shared his love of Africa and, you know, the two traveled extensively through Africa together.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: Chelsy remained a constant in Harry's life for years to come.

utterances.speaker: NIKKHAH
utterances.sentences: She also came into his life at a time when he was missing that female figure to support him, and I think Chelsy did that and understood him. And she could understand that he'd been through a very difficult time and was still going through a very hard time.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: A very hard time that Harry struggled to overcome.When we come back --

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: As Harry navigated the highs and lows of growing up a prince, Meghan Markle was raised a world away from the pomp and circumstance of royal life.

utterances.speaker: COYNE
utterances.sentences: You hear that someone grew up in Los Angeles, and you think about swimming pools and palm trees and Beverly Hills. And Meghan Markle's childhood in L.A. was not that.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: Born in 1981, she's the only child of Doria Ragland and Thomas Markle. While she had two loving parents, Meghan struggled with her biracial identity.

utterances.speaker: JOSH DUBOFF, FORMER SENIOR WRITER, VANITY FAIR
utterances.sentences: Her father was white. Her mother was black. She said when she would fill out forms, there wasn't always a bubble that fit her to fill in.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: While her parents made sure Meghan felt comfortable in her own skin, years of built-up racial tensions in the country exploded right in her own backyard.

utterances.speaker: DUBOFF
utterances.sentences: She was driving, I think, with her mom. And I think there was, like, debris and she thought it was snowing. And then she realized it was actually the L.A. riots.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: Riots that erupted when four white police officers were acquitted in the beating of a black man, Rodney King.

utterances.speaker: COYNE
utterances.sentences: It definitely opened Meghan's eyes to the fact that this was a world that was not always going to treat her fairly, and was not always going to be kind to her or to her family.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: Meghan's early experiences with discrimination were not isolated to race. While watching TV advertisements for a class project, one commercial stood out to her.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED REPORTER
utterances.sentences: Women are fighting greasy pots and pans.

utterances.speaker: DUBOFF
utterances.sentences: They implied that the product was just for women, who were going to be at home doing the cleaning.

utterances.speaker: MEGHAN, DUCHESS OF SUSSEX
utterances.sentences: I don't think it's right for kids to grow up thinking these things. That just mom does everything.

utterances.speaker: COYNE
utterances.sentences: And she wrote a letter.

utterances.speaker: DUCHESS MEGHAN
utterances.sentences: So I was wondering if you would be able to change your commercial to people all over America.

utterances.speaker: COYNE
utterances.sentences: And wouldn't you know it? It worked.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED REPORTER
utterances.sentences: People are fighting greasy pots and pans with Ivory cleaner.

utterances.speaker: COYNE
utterances.sentences: It had to have been such wonderful reinforcement for her at such a young age that she could take a stand and have her voice heard, and not be dismissed.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: Meghan went on to graduate from Northwestern University but returned to Los Angeles to pursue her acting dreams.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Action.CAMEROTA (on-camera): She has said that her 20s were brutal.

utterances.speaker: COYNE
utterances.sentences: Meghan struggled a lot. To become a successful actress, to be able to make a living, that's like winning a lottery ticket. I mean, the number of forces that have to combine to get you even the smallest scrap of success are so astronomical.CAMEROTA (voice-over): Meghan auditioned throughout her 20s. Then, in 2011, she landed a significant role. The female lead on USA network's legal drama "Suits."

utterances.speaker: DUCHESS MEGHAN
utterances.sentences: Is this all a joke to you? Because I take my job seriously.

utterances.speaker: COYNE
utterances.sentences: She got lucky. She undoubtedly handed in a great audition, a great screen test. She had excellent chemistry with her co-stars. And she hit the jackpot.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: "Suits" was an instant hit.

utterances.speaker: COYNE
utterances.sentences: "Suits" radically changed Meghan's life. First and foremost, she was now making more money than she had ever made before, ever.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: As the show achieved success, Meghan made changes in her life, including ending her two-year marriage to Hollywood producer Trevor Engelson.

utterances.speaker: COYNE
utterances.sentences: When they met, she was still largely an aspiring actress. He was an aspiring producer. They were essentially at the same place in their careers. And then "Suits" really took off. And they weren't going in the same direction anymore. She was filming in Toronto. He was in Los Angeles. There were thousands and thousands of miles between them.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: Determined to use her position for good, Meghan advocated for women's equality across the world. Meghan traveled to Rwanda in 2016 as an ambassador for the nonprofit World Vision to highlight the importance of clean drinking water.

utterances.speaker: DUCHESS MEGHAN
utterances.sentences: These girls are able to stay in school because they aren't walking hours a day to go and get water, and this clean water source has changed the entire community.

utterances.speaker: LARA DEWAR, FORMER GLOBAL HEAD OF COMMUNICATIONS AND PUBLIC ENGAGEMENT, WORLD VISION
utterances.sentences: This is not a celebrity who floats in, who needs a platform issue to associate with their, quote-unquote, "brand." This is a woman who's had a desire to help in some way, for a very long time. Promote the faces and stories of women, and to begin to elevate them.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: Coming up.

utterances.speaker: JUNOR
utterances.sentences: He was very angry.

utterances.speaker: JUNOR
utterances.sentences: He started drinking very heavily. He was fed up with who he was.(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: While Meghan was trying to make it in Hollywood, Harry earned a reputation as reckless and self-destructive.

utterances.speaker: JUNOR
utterances.sentences: For many years, it was a real worry about what would happen to Harry because he didn't seem to want to be a royal. He really kicked against it. He wanted to be a normal human being.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: In 2005, Harry joined the British Army where he was one of the guys.

utterances.speaker: PRINCE HARRY
utterances.sentences: As far as I am concerned, I'm out here as a normal J- tech on the ground and not Prince Harry. It's nice to be sort of a normal person. And for once I think this is about as normal as I'm ever going to get.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: Yet there were painful reminders he was still a royal. After 10 weeks in Afghanistan, his mission was leaked and Harry was evacuated.GEN. LORD RICHARD DANNATT, FORMER CHIEF, BRITISH ARMY: It wouldn't have taken Taliban or others long to have searched around and perhaps found where he was. So there was a risk to him. But I think, also, if there was increased risk to him, there was an increased risk to the other soldiers who were around him. And the only sensible and safe thing to do was to bring him back.

utterances.speaker: DANNATT
utterances.sentences: When he came to see me, he sort of sat over slumped in the chair and said the trouble is I can't be like a normal young man. But that time in Afghanistan had given him 10 weeks to be a normal young man, and he desperately wanted to replicate that again. And he accepted and his private secretary accepted that probably the only way he could go back was within the anonymity of being inside a helicopter, and he'd therefore need to learn to fly a helicopter.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: After 18 months of training, Harry not only became an Apache pilot, he was the best co-pilot gunner on his weapons course.

utterances.speaker: JUNOR
utterances.sentences: I actually believe that his success on that Apache, on those Apache aircraft was the making of Harry. I think Harry, who had spent all his life being second best to his brother, being the spare, suddenly found something that he could do and could do better than anybody else. And that gave him confidence that he had never, ever had before. It changed him, I think.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: When Harry left the army after nearly 10 years of service, his future was uncertain.

utterances.speaker: BURRELL
utterances.sentences: I don't think there are any career options for a royal prince. It's easy for William. He is heading towards the throne. I think being royal for Harry was a burden and a curse because he was only the spare. What was his job? What was his way forward?

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: Harry struggled to find his way and to find someone to share his life with. His family and fame had brought an end to his relationship with Chelsy Davy and another serious girlfriend, Cressida Bonas.

utterances.speaker: JUNOR
utterances.sentences: Chelsy had experienced the most horrible treatment. Photographers would be waiting for her. They would call out names. Slag, bitch, whore, trying to get a reaction from her. And I guess that she looked at all of this and thought, do I want this for my life?I think Cressida took one look at what life with Harry would have involved and just turned her back on it. You know? CAMEROTA (on-camera): She didn't want to be a princess.

utterances.speaker: JUNOR
utterances.sentences: I don't think any sane person wants to be a princess.CAMEROTA (voice-over): In 2017, Harry opened up for the first time publicly about his feelings on being a royal in a documentary for the BBC.

utterances.speaker: PRINCE HARRY
utterances.sentences: I spent a long time in my life, my head buried in the sand. You know, thinking I don't want to be Prince Harry. I don't want this responsibility. I don't want this role. You know, look what's happened to my mother. You know, why does this have to happen to me?

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: Harry even considered a drastic move.

utterances.speaker: LEVIN
utterances.sentences: Prince Harry got so low that he decided at one point that he might leave the royal family.

utterances.speaker: NIKKHAH
utterances.sentences: He is living this life that he's been born into. It's not his choice. And I think he felt at times very cross about that.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: In 2017, Harry shared his struggle as part of his Heads Together campaign with Prince William and Kate to end the stigma around mental health.

utterances.speaker: PRINCE HARRY
utterances.sentences: Never really talked about losing my mom at such a young age. I always thought to myself, what's the point of bringing up the past? It ain't going to change it. It ain't going to bring her back. And when you start thinking like that, it can be really damaging.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: And Harry told the BBC he wanted to follow in his mother's footsteps.

utterances.speaker: PRINCE HARRY
utterances.sentences: Now all I want to do is try and, you know, fill the holes that my mother has left. And that's what it's about for us, is trying to make a difference and in making a difference, making her proud.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: He started a charity for the children he met in Lesotho, Africa.

utterances.speaker: NIKKHAH
utterances.sentences: And you look at Harry's work with HIV and AIDS. That was something that his mother, as Harry said, you know, smashed through the stigma of that when she was alive.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: And in 2014, he founded the Invictus Games, an Olympic-style competition that gives wounded veterans and service members a chance to be defined by more than their injuries.

utterances.speaker: PRINCE HARRY
utterances.sentences: It's life-changing. It really is life-changing for them.

utterances.speaker: LEVIN
utterances.sentences: I think he has used his own experience of loss and sadness and bereavement to help these soldiers. And the bereavement doesn't just mean losing someone, it means losing yourself I think, too.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: When we come back, the struggles with being royal.

utterances.speaker: PRINCE HARRY
utterances.sentences: I'd never, never even heard of her until this friend said Meghan Markle. I was like, right, OK. Give me -- give me a bit of background.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: It was July, 2016, in London when Britain's most eligible bachelor, Prince Harry, was set up on a blind date.

utterances.speaker: DUCHESS MEGHAN
utterances.sentences: It was definitely a setup. It was a blind date.

utterances.speaker: PRINCE HARRY
utterances.sentences: I was beautifully surprised when I walked into that room and saw her. And there she was sitting there. I was like, OK, I really have to up my game.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: Harry upped his game and they began a long-distance romance. Meeting up in London and Toronto, where Meghan, then an actress, was filming the TV show "Suits."PATRICK J. ADAMS, ACTOR: Wow, you're pretty.

utterances.speaker: DUCHESS MEGHAN
utterances.sentences: Good. You've hit on me, we can get it out of the way that I am not interested.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: The whole time, they kept their relationship a secret.

utterances.speaker: JUNOR
utterances.sentences: When they first met, nobody knew about it.CAMEROTA (on-camera): Which is itself impressive.

utterances.speaker: JUNOR
utterances.sentences: It is impressive. I mean, the great fear about Harry finding a wife was always going to be the intrusion of the press because that is what had killed two previous long-term relationships.

utterances.speaker: NIKKHAH
utterances.sentences: Harry and his brother still feel that, you know, the paparazzi and press intrusion were certainly partly responsible for his mother's death, and thought, why would anyone want to put up with this for me?

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: Harry wanted to keep his relationship with Meghan private as long as he could. But just four months after that first date, the news was out. And the paparazzi pounced once again.

utterances.speaker: JUNOR
utterances.sentences: I think there was a foot photographer who got inside Meghan's house in Toronto. The paparazzi were camping on her mother's front lawn and following, you know, and harassing all members of her family. Anybody really who knew her.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: Despite starring in a TV show, Meghan was relatively unknown. Now the British press wanted to know who she was and if she was fit for the royal family.

utterances.speaker: NIKKHAH
utterances.sentences: She was a woman who has been married. People were fascinated by the fact that she was divorced. People were fascinated by her background, her acting, a career woman. How would that work being with someone in the royal family? You know, that's not what we've seen before.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: They also had not seen someone biracial dating a member of the royal family. And some of the conversation was blatantly racist.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: There was one newspaper headline saying "Straight Out of Compton," suggesting that she was from a gang-ridden neighborhood and would Harry be dropping around for tea in gangland, which was very clearly racially loaded.

utterances.speaker: COYNE
utterances.sentences: A whole another issue exploded which was the number of rather horrific social media racist comments began to flood in from the darkest, vilest corners of the internet.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: The royal family responded in unprecedented fashion with Prince Harry's team at Kensington Palace releasing a statement confronting the, quote, "abuse and harassment Meghan was facing," saying, "This is not a game. It is her life and his."(On-camera): Why is it that you think that Meghan's upbringing, her race, why did that garner so much attention?

utterances.speaker: JUNOR
utterances.sentences: In the past, members of the royal family, princes, would have married princesses, and when Harry's father, Prince Charles, was looking for a wife, it was also a requirement that a wife should be a virgin and a member of the Church of England.

utterances.speaker: COYNE
utterances.sentences: You just go back a few generations in the royal family. And everything that you can say about Meghan Markle disqualifies her from marrying Harry. This is precisely why you had Edward abdicating his throne so that he could marry an American divorcee. Elizabeth's sister Margaret was in love with a divorced man and was not allowed to marry him.CAMEROTA (on-camera): And wasn't Charles and Diana's wedding and marriage a wake-up call in some ways for the marquee that you can try to have somebody perfect, but it has to be chemistry and you have to love the person and have the freedom to marry who they want?

utterances.speaker: JUNOR
utterances.sentences: I think it was a lesson that they've learned.CAMEROTA (voice-over): In November of 2017, Harry and Meghan announced their engagement.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED REPORTER
utterances.sentences: Kensington Palace announcing the two are set to wed in spring of 2018.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: And the royal family welcomed Meghan with open arms.

utterances.speaker: NIKKHAH
utterances.sentences: The queen made an exception and broke from royal protocol and invited Meghan to spend Christmas with the royal family and the Queen at Sandringham. That's the first time a royal fiancee has ever done that before actually marrying into the royal family.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: A powerful sign the monarchy and the Queen were modernizing and changing.

utterances.speaker: NIKKHAH
utterances.sentences: The royal family now is trying to at least be much more perceptive of society. And the Queen, first and foremost, wants her grandson to be happy. CAMEROTA

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: May 19, 2018. Harry and Meghan married at St. George's Chapel at Windsor Castle.

utterances.speaker: NIKKHAH
utterances.sentences: It was really such an extraordinary national celebration. The whole of the U.K. and so many people around the world were so behind Harry and Meghan and the culmination of that love story.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED REPORTER
utterances.sentences: The new royal couple. You can hear the cheering.CAMEROTA (on-camera): And in terms of public opinion, they were popular.

utterances.speaker: NIKKHAH
utterances.sentences: There is no doubt about that. You just need to see all the coverage in the run-up to the wedding. Harry was one of the most popular members of the royal family for a very long time.

utterances.speaker: JUNOR
utterances.sentences: Meghan seemed to be utterly perfect. And it was fantastic to have somebody of mixed race coming into the royal family, and therefore making it more relevant to so many more people in Britain.CAMEROTA (voice-over): Their popularity continued on their first royal tour to Australia, New Zealand, Fiji and Tonga, where they were treated like rock stars.

utterances.speaker: NIKKHAH
utterances.sentences: They got a rapturous reception everywhere they went, and more importantly, rapturous press coverage, too.CAMEROTA (on-camera): And that was Meghan's first tour as a member of the royal family. So how did she do?

utterances.speaker: NIKKHAH
utterances.sentences: She really took to it incredibly well and it was a great triumph.CAMEROTA (voice-over): And a triumph, it seemed, for the royal family. A new golden couple to help the next generation carry the monarchy forward.

utterances.speaker: JUNOR
utterances.sentences: They looked as though they were the perfect foursome. They were even labeled the fab four. And it did look as though they were all getting along really, really well.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: But soon stories began to leak. That there was tension behind palace doors.

utterances.speaker: JUNOR
utterances.sentences: They had a good relationship, the three of them. Then Meghan arrived, and I think that was when things started to go wrong. [23Harry fell head over heels. Harry is a very impetuous sort of person. William is very much more considered. He is very controlled in what he does, and I think he looked at Harry moving very, very quickly towards marriage and just said, hold on a minute. Are you sure you're not going too fast here?

utterances.speaker: NIKKHAH
utterances.sentences: You look at Harry and William's parents. They didn't take huge amount of time to get to know each other. That marriage was not successful. Whereas, you know, William and Kate spent many years getting to know each other and making sure that she would be able to take on those responsibilities and the weight of responsibility. And I think William probably just wanted to make sure that Meghan knew what she was getting herself into.

utterances.speaker: DURAND
utterances.sentences: What Prince William may have said with brotherly concern, according to sources close to Harry was taken in a very different way. That it wasn't brotherly concern but, perhaps, he had overstepped in a way.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: There were also stories in the press that painted Meghan in an unflattering light.(On-camera): One saying that Meghan made Kate cry during the wedding preparations. What was the truth?

utterances.speaker: NIKKHAH
utterances.sentences: That story has been reported both ways. Of course, Meghan said that it was the other way around. So it's very hard to know.CAMEROTA (voice-over): And there were reports that Meghan was difficult to work for. (On-camera): There were reports that three of the staff of the royal household were going to be leaving.

utterances.speaker: JUNOR
utterances.sentences: It is very unusual. Members of the royal household tend to stay quite a long time. And certainly the stories that I was hearing was that she was very demanding and could be quite difficult.

utterances.speaker: NIKKHAH
utterances.sentences: There was an internal complaint made by one of the senior members of staff about the treatment of other members of staff in the household who worked for Harry and Meghan, and there were allegations that some of the treatment by Meghan towards her press staff was bullying.We know that Meghan has very, very strenuously denied all allegations of bullying against her. Her lawyers have said it's a campaign against her.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: Eventually, Harry and Meghan decided to separate their official office and charity from William and Kate, and they left their home at Kensington Palace for the Frogmore Cottage in Windsor, saying they needed more space for their growing family.

utterances.speaker: JUNOR
utterances.sentences: It was an indication that all was not well with the fab four. They were treading on one another's toes and Harry and Meghan wanted to do things differently.

utterances.speaker: NIKKHAH
utterances.sentences: People within the royal households have said Meghan and Kate were different characters. And we know from a book that was written about them that Meghan felt that she wasn't warmly received enough by Kate.
